text: Nothing says masterclass like a shirtless dude. So today we're going to talk about rolling options. And I'm going to walk you through a quick overview of what it is. You probably already know. I want to get into some of the mechanics that people mess up quite literally all the time. And then at the end of the video, I want to walk you through a bunch of best practices and kind of some commonly asked questions to make sure that we're fully thinking through this process because I can tell you from my own experience and what I regularly see in places like Reddit and on my YouTube comments are when people talk about rolling options, it is very clear that we don't fully understand them. The first time we see them, we have an immediate perception that this is the greatest thing ever. It's going to fix all of our problems. We can just roll things and everything's great. And that's not so much of the case. So I want to walk you through exactly that. And we're going to talk about things like once the best time to roll, should you roll out or up or in or down all of those things are on the docket. So what's up everybody? Welcome back to the outliers and a shout out to the Patreon family, the people in the Patreon actually get free access to the shop, weekly workshops. So if what I do helps you out,

So if what I do helps you out, consider signing up link in the notes below. Let's get right to it. So here is the beginning. What is rolling really simple? It's closing a trade, entering a new one. The what differentiates rolling from closing a trade and opening a new one simple, we tie the accounting together. So what does that look like in practice? Well, we have the first trade where we enter, then we exit and then we enter again. So where's the role in this instance right there? So as we enter this first trade, it's on its working. Then we choose to exit it and then enter a new one and tie the accounting between this position and this new open position together. So what does this look like in terms of money? Well, in this first trade, if we sell to open a put, I just picked a random one for a dollar, then we close it for two dollars. What happened here? We simple. We realized a 100 loss. We collected 1. We close the trade for 2. That means we give up the dollar that we collected up front and then we give up another dollar on top of that.

text: dollar, then we close it for two dollars. What happened here? We simple. We realized a 100 loss. We collected 1. We close the trade for 2. That means we give up the dollar that we collected up front and then we give up another dollar on top of that. That is 100 because obviously you multiply this out by 100 for options. This is where the trade lands. So where's the role? It's right here. If we buy to close at two bucks and then we sell to open at whatever price, you've now completed a role. Common misconception is that roles are only conducted on losing positions. You can roll a winning trade. It's just in generality and parlance. When we talk about it, it's normally referred to in the context of a losing trade, which is actually quite telling when it comes to the mindset of when we roll. This is something I do want to speak about for just a second because it's a common problem people have is that if this was a winning trade that you closed and then opened, you probably wouldn't consider a role. Why is that? Well, it's because you're happy with your win. That's off the books. Now we're entering a new trade. You don't want to tie the accounting to it because you have a win. But when we're rolling very frequently, it's fueled by hope. We hope this next trade overwhelms the loss of the previous trade. So

text: I need to analyze the underlying. So I want to add two weeks and depending on how much I'm improving my basis, does that make sense? So overall, the decision on whether or not you go further out in time comes down to how do you feel about the underlying and running out of DTE liquidity and then rolling down or up depends on how much money you want to make. Because if I try to roll, for example, from the 12 to the 19 DTE, if we look at this scenario and let's say I'm at the 575, so I keep the same strike. In this case, you have what 2675, and this is just called 35 in that scenario, you can still make an okay amount of money by staying at the same strike. If you chose to go from the 575s down to the 570s, notice what happens instead of getting 35, whatever this is, you're going to get 32 in change. So you have to decide what's more important to you. Is it improving your basis, adjusting your basis, or is it collecting more money up front? That is 100 dependent on the trader. So this is part one. As you can tell, it's a big video. There's a lot that goes into this. If you have any questions, let me know if we should do a part two and go even deeper with specific examples, let me know because we might be able to swing
